questions.text:
A 65-year-old man comes to the physician because of a 6-month history of muscle weakness. During this period, the patient has had low energy, intermittent nosebleeds, and a 5-kg (11-lb) weight loss. He also reports progressive hearing and vision problems. He has a history of pins-and-needles sensation, numbness, and pain in his feet. Vital signs are within normal limits. Physical examination shows a palpable liver tip 2–3 cm below the right costal margin. There is nontender lympadenopathy in the groin, axillae, and neck. Laboratory studies show:


Hemoglobin
8.8 g/dL


Leukocyte count
6300/mm3



Platelet count
98,000/mm3



Erythrocyte sedimentation rate
70 mm/h


Serum



 Na+

136 mmol/L


 K+

3.6 mmol/L


 Ca2+

8.6 mg/dL


 Creatinine
1.3 mg/dL


 AST
32 U/L


 ALT
36 U/L


 Alkaline phosphatase
130 U/L


 Lactate dehydrogenase
220 U/L


A serum protein electrophoresis exhibits a sharp, narrow spike of monoclonal IgM immunoglobulin. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Chronic lymphocytic leukemia (CLL) primarily occurs in older patients (> 70 years) and could explain this patient's fatigue, weight loss, generalized painless lymphadenopathy, anemia, thrombocytopenia, hyperviscosity syndrome (as indicated by progressive vision and hearing loss), and hepatomegaly. However, CLL is associated with further features, such as lymphocytosis, a history of recurrent infections (e.g., necrotic erysipelas, candidiasis, and/or herpes zoster), and polyclonal gammopathy (i.e., broad-based peak representing a polyclonal increase in immunoglobulins) rather than monoclonal gammopathy (i.e., single spike of monoclonal IgM immunoglobulin).

B) INCORRECT:

Hairy cell leukemia affects middle-aged men and causes anemia and thrombocytopenia. However, B symptoms and lymphadenopathy are typically absent. Also, usually massive splenomegaly dominates, recurrent infections occur (due to leukopenia), and the B cells do not lead to monoclonal protein production.

C) INCORRECT:

Multiple myeloma (MM) can manifest with weight loss, fatigue, hyperviscosity syndrome (as indicated by progressive vision and hearing loss), and bleeding susceptibility along with a monoclonal spike on electrophoresis in older individuals. However, enlarged lymph nodes are not a typical finding in MM. Moreover, this condition is typically associated with excess production of IgG or IgA, not IgM. In addition, the CRAB symptoms (hypercalcemia, renal disease, anemia, and bone lesions) are classically present to varying degrees. This patient is normocalcemic with adequate renal function and has not reported any bone pain, making MM a less likely diagnosis.

D) CORRECT:

Waldenstrom macroglobulinemia is an indolent type of non-Hodgkin lymphoma that is caused by abnormal production of IgM antibodies by monoclonal plasma cells. This condition usually manifests in older patients with impaired platelet function (nosebleeds), anemia, and mild thrombocytopenia, progressive neuropathy (history of pain and numbness in the feet, muscle weakness), and hyperviscosity syndrome (vision and hearing loss). Lymph node enlargement, as well as increased erythrocyte sedimentation rate, lactate dehydrogenase, and alkaline phosphatase can also be present. Serum protein electrophoresis demonstrating a dense, monoclonal IgM band is essential for diagnosis. Treatment includes administration of CD20 antibodies (e.g., rituximab) and plasmapheresis in case of hyperviscosity syndrome.

Hyperviscosity syndrome is present in about 30% of patients with Waldenstrom macroglobulinemia. This condition is not caused by an increase in hematocrit but rather from the clumping effects induced by the pathologically elevated serum IgM concentrations (i.e., IgM act as cold agglutinins).

E) INCORRECT:

This patient's age (> 45 years old) and abnormal production of monoclonal immunoglobulins are consistent with monoclonal gammopathy of undetermined significance (MGUS). However, MGUS is, by definition, not associated with any accompanying clinical symptoms.

F) INCORRECT:

Mantle cell lymphoma also affects older males (65–70 years) and causes painless, generalized lymphadenopathy, hepatomegaly, increased lactate dehydrogenase, and constitutional symptoms. However, mantle cell lymphoma is usually also associated with extensive splenomegaly and gastrointestinal discomfort and pain due to stomach and colon involvement. Simultaneous vision and hearing changes are not typically seen and monoclonal proliferation is very rare. Although this condition cannot be ruled out completely in this case, another option is much more likely.
questions.hint: A bone marrow biopsy in this patient would show intranuclear inclusions of IgM deposits in plasma cells, also known as Dutcher bodies.

questions.text: A 70-year-old man comes to the physician because of progressive fatigue and lower back pain for the past 4 months. The back pain worsened significantly after he had a minor fall while doing yard work the previous day. The patient's brother died of prostate cancer at the age of 75 years. His vital signs are within normal limits. Examination shows bilateral paravertebral muscle spasm, severe tenderness over the second lumbar vertebra, and mild tenderness over the lower thoracic vertebrae. Neurologic examination shows no abnormalities. His hemoglobin concentration is 10.5 g/dl, serum alkaline phosphatase concentration is 90 U/L, and serum calcium concentration is 11.1 mg/dl. An x-ray of the skull is shown. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Bone marrow biopsy showing ≥ 10% clonal plasma cells is the confirmatory test of choice in patients with suspected MM. While this patient's symptoms are highly suggestive of MM, bone marrow biopsy is an invasive test that is only performed after monoclonal protein production has been confirmed with the appropriate screening test.

B) CORRECT:

Serum protein electrophoresis (SPEP) is an initial screening test in patients with suspected MM. SPEP can detect monoclonal production of a protein by a malignant plasma cell, showing a characteristic abnormal peak (M spike) in the γ-globulin region. Subsequent serum immunofixation enables determination of the type of monoclonal protein, with most cases being due to abnormal production of IgG (50%) or IgA (25%). In patients with MM, anemia (and possibly thrombocytopenia and leukopenia) results from bone marrow infiltration by malignant plasma cells with suppression of normal hematopoiesis. Hypercalcemia is caused by increased production of osteoclast-activating factors that result in osteolysis.

If SPEP confirms abnormal plasma cell protein production, a 24-hour urinary collection for protein electrophoresis and immunofixation is indicated to detect the possible presence of light chains in the urine (Bence Jones protein), which can cause renal failure due to cast nephropathy.
Image Description:

Pathological protein electrophoresis in multiple myeloma: the monoclonal antibodies cause a peak in the gamma-globulin zone of the electrophoresis, which is termed M protein (also M component, myeloma protein, spike protein, and paraprotein).

C) INCORRECT:

Hemoglobin electrophoresis is used in the diagnosis of hemoglobinopathies, including thalassemias. While the homozygote form of beta-thalassemia (thalassemia major) can cause anemia, skeletal abnormalities, and pathologic fractures, the diagnosis is typically established at age 6–12 months, when affected children present with pallor, jaundice, hepatosplenomegaly (due to extramedullary hematopoiesis). Untreated children with beta-thalassemia major will die of their disease, ruling out this diagnosis in this 70-year-old. Also, rather than the punched-out lytic lesions seen on the skull x-ray in this patient, patients with beta-thalassemia major have characteristic skeletal deformities with a high forehead and prominent zygomatic bones and maxilla (chipmunk facies) due to expansion of the bone marrow.

D) INCORRECT:

In adults, a deficiency of vitamin D causes osteomalacia, which can also manifest with bone pain and pathologic fractures. However, low levels of vitamin D impair intestinal resorption of calcium, resulting in hypocalcemia. Alkaline phosphatase is typically elevated in osteomalacia due to increased bone turnover. Furthermore, patients with osteomalacia would present with generalized low bone mineral density and thin cortices on x-ray rather than the localized osteolytic lesions seen here. Also, anemia is not a feature of osteomalacia; instead, patients typically complain of muscle weakness and difficulty walking.

E) INCORRECT:

An MRI of the spine can help to determine the neurologic involvement in patients with vertebral fractures. While this patient's history of recent trauma and the severe tenderness over the second lumbar vertebra are suggestive of a vertebral fracture, the absence of neurologic symptoms (e.g., weakness, numbness, urinary incontinence) and the normal neurologic exam make spinal compression less likely. An anterior-posterior and lateral x-ray of the spine should be obtained first to assess the integrity of the vertebral column.

F) INCORRECT:

Prostate biopsy is used to diagnose prostate cancer (PCa), which, in a metastatic stage, can manifest with fatigue, back pain, pathologic fractures, and bone lesions on x-ray. This patient's family history of prostate cancer puts him at increased risk for this condition. However, PCa metastases are typically osteoblastic (rather than osteolytic), manifesting with sclerotic lesions and increased alkaline phosphatase. Moreover, because of the lack of osteolytic activity in patients with PCa, hypercalcemia is not a common laboratory finding. Furthermore, a digital rectal examination and measurement of prostate-specific antigen would be indicated prior to pathologic confirmation of prostate cancer.
Image Description:

X-ray pelvis (AP view) of a patient with prostate cancer:

Numerous sclerotic metastases are seen throughout the pelvis, lumbar spine, and proximal femurs (examples indicated by green overlay). Also seen is avascular necrosis (osteonecrosis) of the right hip, with marked fragmentation of the femoral head (indicated by red overlay) and superior subluxation of the femur (asymmetry indicated by dashed lines).

G) INCORRECT:

A bone scan can be used in the diagnosis of Paget disease of bone, which typically affects older men. Paget disease of bone may also manifest with bone pain, pathologic fractures, and osteolytic skull lesions. However, affected patients usually have elevated alkaline phosphatase and normal serum calcium. Moreover, radiographs of patients with Paget disease of bone usually show a mixed picture of both sclerotic and osteolytic lesions, as well as a thickened calvaria. Also, this patient lacks other features of the disease, such as skull enlargement, cranial nerve deficits, or hearing loss.
Image Description:

X-ray skull (lateral view)

The calvarium is markedly thickened (left right arrow), with widening of the diploic space. Numerous ill-defined lytic (examples indicated by green overlay) and sclerotic (examples indicated by red overlay) lesions are present.

The presence of multiple poorly marginated sclerotic lesions in Paget disease has been termed “cotton wool appearance.”
questions.hint: This patient presents with fatigue, bone pain, and a possible pathological vertebral fracture. In combination with anemia, hypercalcemia, and multiple lytic lesions ("punched-out" holes) in the skull on x-ray, these features suggest multiple myeloma (MM).

questions.text:
A 68-year-old woman comes to the physician with increasing fatigue and shortness of breath for 2 weeks. She has only passed very small amounts of urine over the past few days. During this time, she has also noticed that her feet appear unusually puffy for a few hours every morning. Three weeks ago, she had a sore throat that resolved spontaneously after several days without antibiotic therapy. She has a 6-month history of lower back and thoracic pain, for which she takes ibuprofen daily. Her only other medication is a laxative for constipation, which she first experienced 8 months ago. Her sister has systemic lupus erythematosus. Her temperature is 37.9°C (98.9°F), pulse is 110/min, respirations are 22/min, and blood pressure is 150/100 mm Hg. Examination shows pedal edema and conjunctival pallor. There is tenderness to palpation over the lumbar spine and the 8th rib on the right. Cardiac examination shows no abnormalities. Laboratory studies show:


Hemoglobin
9.8 g/dL


Serum



 Urea nitrogen
50 mg/dL


 Creatinine

2.8 mg/dL


 Calcium

12.9 mg/dL


Urine dipstick is negative for blood and protein. Which of the following is the most likely underlying cause of this patient's symptoms?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Anti-dsDNA antibodies are typically found in systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE). By cross-reacting with the glomerular basement membrane, they promote an inflammatory response, which may result in lupus nephritis. This patient's family history of SLE, renal failure, lower back pain (possibly due to arthritis), and fatigue are supportive of this diagnosis. However, she lacks other classic findings of underlying SLE such as fever, cardiac abnormalities, and/or a malar rash. Lastly, hematuria and proteinuria are common in lupus nephritis, but are not present here.

B) INCORRECT:

Hypersensitivity reaction is the underlying pathomechanism of allergic interstitial nephritis, which may occur in patients with long-term use of analgesic agents, including ibuprofen. However, allergic interstitial nephritis is not associated with hypercalcemia and bone pain. Moreover, this condition usually manifests with fever, colicky flank pain (due to papillary necrosis), and/or hematuria, none of which is present in this patient.

C) INCORRECT:

Antiglomerular basement membrane antibodies (anti-GBM antibodies) are present in Goodpasture syndrome, which can also cause dyspnea, fatigue, and renal failure with edema in an older patient. However, Goodpasture syndrome is not associated with bone pain and hypercalcemia. Moreover, this patient lacks signs of pulmonary involvement (e.g., hemoptysis, cough) and the renal failure seen in Goodpasture syndrome is typically rapidly progressive with evidence of proteinuria and hematuria on urinalysis.

D) INCORRECT:

Renal deposition of AL amyloid (immunoglobulin light chain proteins) suggests light-chain amyloidosis, which may occur secondary to MM. Light-chain amyloidosis is typically rapidly progressive and affects multiple organ systems, such as the kidneys (nephrotic syndrome with proteinuria and orthostatic hypotension), heart (restrictive cardiomyopathy, atrioventricular block), and gastrointestinal tract (malabsorption syndromes). This patient has no cardiac abnormalities, and urinalysis was negative for proteins.

E) CORRECT:

Precipitation of excessive nephrotoxic immunoglobulin light chains (Bence Jones proteins) leads to myeloma cast nephropathy, which is the most common cause of renal failure in patients with MM. The light chains cause eosinophilic intratubular cast formation and obstruction. They have a direct toxic effect on the renal tubular epithelial cells, resulting in tubular atrophy. A dipstick urine test cannot detect light chain proteins in the urine, since it is specific for albumin. Myeloma cast nephropathy is diagnosed via a positive urine sulfosalicylic acid test and/or urine protein electrophoresis. Besides myeloma cast nephropathy, renal disease in MM patients may be due to various other mechanisms, including light-chain amyloidosis (usually manifesting with nephrotic syndrome due to glomerular dysfunction) or hypercalcemia (causing nephrocalcinosis).

Therapy of myeloma cast nephropathy includes treatment of MM and hypercalcemia, forced diuresis, removal of the offending agent (e.g., NSAIDs), and, if progression to end-stage renal disease occurs, dialysis, plasmapheresis, or transplantation.

F) INCORRECT:

Cardiac ejection fraction is decreased in patients with congestive heart failure (CHF), which may cause prerenal acute kidney injury due to renal hypoperfusion. While CHF may also manifest with edema and dyspnea, the bone pain and hypercalcemia in this patient are better explained by another cause.

G) INCORRECT:

Anti-streptococcal antibodies (e.g., antistreptolysin O) can be found in post-streptococcal glomerulonephritis (PSGN), which can occur 1–3 weeks following group A streptococcal tonsillopharyngitis, especially in children or immunocompromised patients. While this patient had a sore throat 3 weeks ago and PSGN may also cause lower back pain, peripheral edema, and dyspnea (in cases of pulmonary edema), hematuria, and hypertension would also be expected due to nephritic syndrome. This patient's findings are better explained by another cause.
questions.hint: This patient presents with fatigue, features of renal failure (dyspnea, oliguria, peripheral edema, elevated blood urea nitrogen and creatinine), persistent bone pain, anemia, and symptomatic hypercalcemia, the combination of which suggests multiple myeloma (MM).

questions.text:
A 69-year-old woman comes to the physician because of lower back pain and right-sided chest pain for the past month. The pain is aggravated by movement. Over the past 2 months, she has had increasing fatigue. She has hypertension and reflux disease. Her mother died of breast cancer. Current medications include metoprolol and omeprazole. Vital signs are within normal limits. Examination shows full muscle strength. There is tenderness to palpation over the lower spine and the right lateral chest. The remainder of the examination shows no abnormalities. Laboratory studies show:


Hemoglobin
9.5 g/dL


Leukocyte count
7300/mm3



Platelet count
230,000/mm3



Serum



Na+

137 mEq/L


K+

3.5 mEq/L


 Creatinine

1.3 mg/dL


An ECG shows no evidence of ischemia. An x-ray of the chest shows lytic lesions in 2 ribs. Blood smear shows aggregations of erythrocytes. Protein electrophoresis of the serum with immunofixation shows an M-protein spike. This patient's condition is most likely associated with which of the following findings?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

MM is associated with an increased risk of infection (most commonly urinary tract infection and pneumonia) because of the uncontrolled production of ineffective, monoclonal immunoglobulins (commonly IgA and IgG) and lymphocyte dysfunction. Infections are a major cause of death in patients with MM.

Another characteristic finding in MM is Bence Jones protein on urinary protein electrophoresis.

B) INCORRECT:

Leukemic hiatus is a common diagnostic finding in laboratory studies of patients with acute myeloid leukemia (AML). This patient presents with some features that are typical of AML, including anemia and fatigue. However, individuals with AML typically have B symptoms, hepatomegaly, and/or splenomegaly; an M-protein spike on serum protein electrophoresis and lytic bone lesions on x-ray are not expected. This patient most likely has MM, which is not associated with leukemic hiatus.

C) INCORRECT:

Causes of splenomegaly include increased splenic activity (due to e.g., increased immune response to viral infections), decreased venous drainage (due to portal hypertension) and infiltration of the spleen (due to e.g., tumors, metabolic diseases). While splenomegaly is a common finding in individuals with other hematologic malignancies (e.g., chronic myeloid leukemia, Hodgkin lymphoma), it is present in only ∼ 1% of patients with MM.

D) INCORRECT:

Jaundice can be caused by various conditions and often indicates liver pathology or hemolysis. This patient has a family history of breast cancer, which puts her at higher risk for this disease, and liver involvement due to metastases is possible. However, there are no further findings to suggest breast cancer in this patient. Jaundice can also be caused by hemolytic anemia secondary to some hematologic malignancies (e.g. non-Hodgkin lymphoma, chronic lymphocytic leukemia). However, this patient is likely to have MM, which rarely causes hemolytic anemia.

E) INCORRECT:

Autoimmune hemolytic anemia (AIHA) can be secondary to diseases such as chronic lymphocytic leukemia (warm AIHA) and Waldenstrom macroglobulinemia (cold AIHA). While this patient's anemia, fatigue, and older age may suggest chronic lymphocytic leukemia, she does not have other typical features of this condition, such as B symptoms, painless lymphadenopathy, hepatosplenomegaly, lymphocytosis, and smudge cells on peripheral blood smear. Waldenstrom macroglobulinemia can also manifest with anemia, fatigue, renal impairment, rouleaux formation on peripheral blood smear, and an M-protein spike on serum protein electrophoresis. However, Waldenstrom macroglobulinemia is typically associated with additional features such as peripheral neuropathy, susceptibility to bleeding, and Raynaud phenomenon. Finally, this patient's bone pain and osteolytic lesions on x-ray indicate MM, which is not associated with AIHA.
questions.hint: This patient presents with bone pain, anemia, elevated creatinine, rouleaux formation (aggregation of erythrocytes) on peripheral blood smear, an M-protein spike on serum protein electrophoresis, and lytic bone lesions on x-ray, making multiple myeloma (MM) the most likely diagnosis.

questions.text:
A 71-year-old man comes to the physician for a routine health maintenance examination. Aside from occasional lower back pain over the last couple of years, he feels well. He had a right-sided myocardial infarction 4 years ago. Currently, he has no shortness of breath or anginal symptoms. He smoked one pack of cigarettes daily but quit 10 years ago and does not drink alcohol. His pulse is 59/min and blood pressure is 135/75 mm Hg. Physical examination shows 1+ lower extremity edema. Cardiac and pulmonary examination show no abnormalities. There is no lymphadenopathy or organomegaly. Laboratory studies show:


Hemoglobin
13.5 g/dL


Leukocyte count
6500/mm3



Platelet count
210,000/mm3



Serum



Na+

140 mEq/L


K+

4.2 mEq/L


Ca+

10.1 mg/dL


Protein
9.8 g/dL


Creatinine
1.0 mg/dL


An ECG shows the same known Q-wave abnormalities seen on the last ECG 1 year ago. Serum protein electrophoresis shows an isolated peak of the gamma zone. Serum immunofixation shows excessive production of IgG and the kappa light chain; the kappa to lambda free light chain ratio is within the reference range. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Bone densitometry or dual-energy x-ray absorptiometry (DEXA scan) is the imaging modality of choice for the diagnosis of osteoporosis. It is used to measure bone mineral density of the lumbar spine or proximal femur, to calculate the T-score, and to assess the risk of future fractures. Although longstanding MM can result in osteopenia, it would cause multiple focal lytic lesions throughout the skeleton, which would not be detected by a DEXA scan.

B) INCORRECT:

Renal biopsy can be used to assess the pathological changes in patients with plasma cell dyscrasias. Although all patients with suspected plasma cell dyscrasias should be evaluated for end-organ damage, renal biopsy is not routinely performed to determine the presence of renal insufficiency.

C) INCORRECT:

Echocardiography would be warranted in a patient with a history of myocardial infarction (MI) who shows signs of right-sided heart failure. Although this patient has mild bilateral pitting edema, he has no anginal symptoms or dyspnea, and the physical examination was otherwise unremarkable. ECG should show typical signs of previous MI (abnormal Q wave), as would be expected in this patient. More importantly, however, this patient has suspected plasma cell dyscrasia and should be assessed according to the CRAB criteria to rule out organ damage related to MM.

D) CORRECT:

This patient's findings on SPEP and immunofixation raise concern for monoclonal gammopathy of undetermined significance (MGUS) or, possibly, MM. MGUS and MM are distinguished based on the CRAB criteria as well as the quantity of serum M protein and bone marrow clonal plasma cells. The CRAB criteria indicate end-organ damage and include hypercalcemia, renal insufficiency, anemia, and/or bone lesions. While this patient has normal concentrations of calcium, creatinine, and hemoglobin, his history of back pain is an indication to perform a low-dose whole-body CT scan to assess for osteolytic bone lesions, a characteristic finding in MM. In addition, a bone marrow biopsy to confirm the diagnosis may be indicated if clinical concern for MM is high; a plasma cell percentage < 10% suggests MGUS while ≥ 10% clonal bone marrow plasma cells confirms MM.

Recommended alternatives to CT include whole-body MRI and PET scan. Plain radiograph skeletal surveys, although cost-effective, are less sensitive and typically reserved for patients with contraindications to preferred imaging modalities.

E) INCORRECT:

Proteinuria in MM is a product of overexpressed serum immunoglobulin. The urine dipstick test specifically tests for protein albumin, not immunoglobulin fragments, and is therefore not an appropriate test in the workup of MM. If plasma cell dyscrasia is suspected, a 24-hour urine collection with urine electrophoresis and creatinine clearance would be one of the indicated tests.
questions.hint: The combination of a monoclonal protein spike (M spike) on serum protein electrophoresis (SPEP) and overproduction of IgG on immunofixation indicate a plasma cell dyscrasia. This patient should undergo evaluation for end-organ damage related to multiple myeloma (MM).

questions.text: A previously healthy 70-year-old man is brought to the emergency department by his wife because of lethargy, confusion, and nausea for the past 2 days. His past medical history is unremarkable. His only medications are a daily multivitamin and acetaminophen, which he takes daily for hip pain that started 2 months ago. Vital signs are within normal limits. He is disoriented to place and time but recognizes his wife. The remainder of the examination shows no abnormalities. Laboratory studies show a hemoglobin concentration of 9.1 g/dL, a serum calcium concentration of 14.7 mg/dL, and a serum creatinine concentration of 2.2 mg/dL. According to the patient's medical records, the results of laboratory studies, including a complete blood count and serum concentrations of electrolytes and creatinine, performed 5 months ago were within the reference ranges. Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient's condition?

choices.text: Decreased excretion of calcium from renal tubular cells
Increased secretion of PTH from parathyroid chief cells
Release of osteoclast activating factors from malignant plasma cells
Release of PTH-related protein from malignant renal cells

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Chronic kidney injury (CKI), which manifests with elevated serum creatinine, can lead to decreased glomerular filtration (i.e., low filter load) and, subsequently, decreased excretion of calcium from renal tubular cells. However, in CKI, hypocalcemia rather than hypercalcemia is observed. In patients with CKI, hypocalcemia results from decreased renal hydroxylation of vitamin D, which reduces intestinal calcium absorption, and decreased renal excretion of phosphate, which causes hyperphosphatemia and subsequent calcium phosphate precipitation in tissues. The development of hypercalcemia, elevated serum creatinine, and anemia within the past 5 months makes this diagnosis unlikely.

B) INCORRECT:

Excessive intake of calcium, e.g., through excessive intake of dietary supplements, causes milk-alkali syndrome, which can manifest with symptoms of hypercalcemia. However, milk-alkali syndrome would not explain this patient's anemia or hip pain.

C) INCORRECT:

Increased production of calcitriol (i.e., hypervitaminosis D) can cause increased intestinal calcium absorption and bone resorption, leading to hypercalcemia. Hypervitaminosis D can occur in patients with granulomatous diseases (e.g., sarcoidosis) or lymphoma secondary to increased expression of 1-alpha-hydroxylase. Although lymphoma can cause anemia of chronic disease, this patient has no other characteristic symptoms (e.g., lymphadenopathy), and hip pain and increased serum creatinine levels are not typical features of lymphoma. In addition, this patient has no symptoms suggestive of granulomatous disease.

D) INCORRECT:

Increased parathyroid hormone (PTH) secretion indicates hyperparathyroidism, which, in combination with elevated calcium, suggests either primary hyperparathyroidism or, in rare cases, tertiary hyperparathyroidism. In both conditions, oversecretion of PTH increases calcium release from the bone and calcium reabsorption by the kidney, which may result in bone pain (e.g., hip pain) and signs of hypercalcemia (e.g., lethargy, confusion, vomiting). In addition, tertiary hyperparathyroidism can manifest with anemia and can be caused by longstanding chronic kidney disease, which manifests with elevated serum creatinine. However, a normal serum creatinine level 5 months prior makes tertiary hyperparathyroidism unlikely. In addition, primary hyperparathyroidism does not cause anemia, making another diagnosis more likely.

E) CORRECT:

This patient's presentation (i.e., hypercalcemia, anemia, elevated serum creatinine, and hip pain) indicates multiple myeloma (MM), a plasma cell dyscrasia characterized by overproliferation and diffuse infiltration of monoclonal plasma cells in the bone marrow. In MM, cell proliferation increases the secretion of proosteoclastogenic factors (e.g., TNF-α, IL-1), which leads to osteolysis, and, consequently, hypercalcemia and diffuse bone pain. In addition, neoplastic cell infiltration in the bone marrow suppresses hematopoiesis, resulting in pancytopenia. Patients with MM also have an increased risk of infection due to the overproduction of nonfunctional antibodies.

This patient should undergo prompt evaluation for MM with serum and urine protein electrophoresis, a free light chain assay, and imaging to assess for bone lesions (e.g., whole-body low-dose CT scan). Bone marrow biopsy should also be performed to confirm the diagnosis.

F) INCORRECT:

Release of PTH-related protein from malignant renal cells is a common cause of hypercalcemia in patients with renal cell carcinoma (RCC). While RCC can cause bone pain (due to bone metastases or hypercalcemia) and anemia in addition to hypercalcemia, other features such as hematuria, flank pain, and a palpable flank mass would also be expected. Moreover, serum creatinine levels are usually normal in patients with unilateral RCC.
questions.hint: This patient has severe hypercalcemia, manifesting with lethargy, confusion, and nausea. The development of hypercalcemia, anemia, renal dysfunction (as indicated by the increased serum creatinine concentration), and bone pain (hip pain) over a relatively short period of time (laboratory studies were normal 5 months ago) raises concern for a malignant etiology.

questions.text: A 71-year-old woman comes to the physician because of progressive shortness of breath and swollen legs for the past 4 weeks. She has tried sleeping in a raised position using 2 pillows but still wakes up occasionally from a choking sensation. She has type 2 diabetes mellitus, arterial hypertension, and gastroesophageal reflux disease. Her sister has polymyalgia rheumatica. Her current medications include insulin, enalapril, and omeprazole. She has smoked one half-pack of cigarettes daily for 45 years. Her temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 112/min, respirations are 22/min, and blood pressure is 119/76 mm Hg. Pulse oximetry on room air shows an oxygen saturation of 90%. Examination shows an enlarged tongue, pitting edema below the knees, and jugular venous distention. Crackles are heard at both lung bases. Her hemoglobin concentration is 9.0 g/dL, leukocyte count is 6100/mm3, erythrocyte sedimentation rate is 62 mm/h, and serum creatinine is 2.1 mg/dL. An ECG shows sinus rhythm and low-voltage QRS complexes. Echocardiography shows symmetrical left ventricular hypertrophy, reduced diastolic filling, and an ejection fraction of 55%. Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient's symptoms?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Endocardial fibroelastosis can cause restrictive cardiomyopathy, but it most commonly affects infants in the first year of life and would not explain the recent development of symptoms in this patient or the finding of macroglossia.

B) INCORRECT:

Systemic sclerosis can result in restrictive cardiomyopathy. However, this condition typically causes patchy myocardial fibrosis leading to systolic ventricular dysfunction or, more often, diastolic ventricular dysfunction. Systemic sclerosis can also present with esophageal hypomotility; although this patient reports a choking sensation, her presentation is more consistent with paroxysmal nocturnal dyspnea due to heart failure or obstructive sleep apnea due to macroglossia given that she wakes up at night and her symptoms are not postprandial. Characteristic facial features in patients with systemic sclerosis include mask-like facies, a shortened frenulum, and microstomia accompanied by characteristic perioral wrinkles rather than macroglossia.

C) CORRECT:

Plasma cell dyscrasias such as multiple myeloma (MM) can be complicated by AL amyloidosis, which causes widespread protein deposition in several organs, including the heart and tongue, with consequent development of restrictive cardiomyopathy and macroglossia. Restrictive cardiomyopathy typically manifests as heart failure with preserved ejection fraction, while macroglossia may cause obstructive sleep apnea, which can result in a choking sensation at night. Highly elevated ESR, Hb < 10 g/dL, and serum creatinine > 2 mg/dL are consistent with MM. Serum protein electrophoresis is the best initial test to detect monoclonal gammopathy in both conditions, but bone marrow biopsy and a tissue amyloid stain are required to confirm the diagnosis of MM and AL amyloidosis, respectively.

See “Overview of systemic amyloidosis” table.

D) INCORRECT:

Cardiac involvement of hemochromatosis typically manifests with dilated cardiomyopathy, although it can also cause restrictive cardiomyopathy. About 50% of patients with hemochromatosis develop diabetes mellitus from the accumulation of iron in the pancreas. However, this patient lacks other typical clinical manifestations of hemochromatosis, including skin pigmentation and liver disease. Moreover, this diagnosis does not explain the finding of macroglossia.

E) INCORRECT:

Cardiac manifestations of rheumatoid arthritis (RA) are uncommon extraarticular manifestations and do not include restrictive cardiomyopathy but rather pericarditis and myocarditis. This patient does not have signs of myocarditis or pericarditis, such as fever or chest pain, and these conditions would not explain the tongue findings. Like other chronic inflammatory conditions, RA can also cause reactive amyloidosis (AA amyloidosis) in rare cases, which typically manifests with renal and gastrointestinal involvement. Unlike another form of amyloidosis, macroglossia and restrictive cardiomyopathy would not be expected in reactive amyloidosis.

F) INCORRECT:

Viral myocarditis can cause acute heart failure and an elevated ESR. Although myocarditis may result in dilated cardiomyopathy with a reduced ejection fraction, restrictive cardiomyopathy with preserved ejection fraction is not typical. If the pericardium is involved (perimyocarditis), pericardial effusions can lead to low-voltage on ECG; however, echocardiography shows no pericardial effusion here. Moreover, myocarditis commonly manifests with constitutional symptoms (e.g., fever, fatigue, myalgia), new evidence of cardiac arrhythmias (e.g., sinus tachycardia, concave ST-segment elevations), and chest pain. Finally, this diagnosis is not consistent with the findings of macroglossia, anemia, and elevated serum creatinine.
Image Description:

12-lead ECG (paper speed: 25 mm/s)

- Sinus rhythm
- Heart rate approx. 65/min
- Normal heart axis (R > S in I and aVF)
- PR-interval duration approx. 120–160 ms
- Narrow QRS complex (approx. 100 ms)
- Concave ST elevations from a descending R wave in leads II, aVF, and V5–V6
- ST elevation (I and V4)

Unlike myocardial infarction, perimyocarditis does not manifest with ST elevations that correspond with the anatomy of coronary arteries.
questions.hint: This patient presents with signs of heart failure (dyspnea, JVD, peripheral and pulmonary edema), low-voltage QRS complexes on ECG, and symmetrical wall thickening with reduced diastolic filling on echocardiography, all of which are consistent with restrictive cardiomyopathy. The combination of restrictive cardiomyopathy and macroglossia suggests AL amyloidosis.

questions.text: A 74-year-old man comes to the physician because of a 2-month history of shortness of breath and leg swelling. He has trouble climbing one flight of stairs due to dyspnea. He has hypertension and was diagnosed with multiple myeloma 6 months ago. Current medications include hydrochlorothiazide. Cardiopulmonary examination shows jugular venous distention, bibasilar crackles, and pitting edema in the lower extremities. Transthoracic echocardiography shows a thickened myocardium with elevated diastolic filling pressures. Which of the following is the most likely underlying mechanism of this patient's cardiomyopathy?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Chronic vasoconstriction can develop in long-term cocaine use and is due to alpha-1 receptor stimulation. Cocaine is toxic to the myocardium, causes myocardial thinning, and can lead to dilated cardiomyopathy (usually seen on echocardiography). However, this patient's TTE did not support the diagnosis of dilated cardiomyopathy and he has no history of substance abuse.

B) INCORRECT:

Myosin gene mutation is an autosomal dominant mutation seen in patients with hypertrophic cardiomyopathy (HCM), and the obstructive type of this disease can cause congestive heart failure. Multiple myeloma, however, is not associated with myosin gene mutation. Moreover, HCM is usually seen in young male athletes with a positive family history.

C) CORRECT:

Amyloid plaque is a common sequela of multiple myeloma and forms as a result of excess production of monoclonal immunoglobulins. Immunoglobulins can deposit in any organ, including the heart, in which case they cause a specific type of restrictive cardiomyopathy known as infiltrative cardiomyopathy. Thickening of the myocardium results in diastolic dysfunction and back-flow of blood causes shortness of breath, jugular venous distention, and pulmonary edema, which are all seen here.

D) INCORRECT:

Chronic hypercalcemia is often seen in patients with multiple myeloma. Hypercalcemia can have a wide range of findings, including constipation, bone pains, and psychiatric mood disorders. Cardiomyopathy, however, is not caused by hypercalcemia.

E) INCORRECT:

Iron deposition can lead to restrictive cardiomyopathy (although dilated cardiomyopathy is more common). Hemochromatosis is one condition that is associated with a high iron state. Patients with this condition can develop cardiomyopathy as a result of iron deposition, which presents with symptoms similar to those seen in this patient, including shortness of breath and JVD. However, other features typically associated with hemochromatosis (e.g., bronzed skin, diabetes, arthralgia) would be expected.
questions.hint: Multiple myeloma is characterized by the production of monoclonal immunoglobulins.

questions.text: A 75-year-old man comes to the physician because of fatigue and decreased urine output for 1 week. He takes ibuprofen as needed for lower back pain and docusate for constipation. Physical examination shows tenderness to palpation over the lumbar spine. There is pedal edema. Laboratory studies show a hemoglobin concentration of 8.7 g/dL, a serum creatinine concentration of 2.3 mg/dL, and a serum calcium concentration of 12.6 mg/dL. Urine dipstick is negative for blood and protein. Which of the following is the most likely underlying cause of this patient's symptoms?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Antiglomerular basement membrane antibodies (anti-GBM antibodies) suggest Goodpasture syndrome, which can also cause fatigue and renal failure with edema, as seen in this patient. However, this patient lacks signs of pulmonary involvement (e.g., hemoptysis, cough) and renal failure is typically rapidly progressive with proteinuria and hematuria. The bone pain and constipation in this patient are better explained by another cause.

B) CORRECT:

Precipitation of excessive nephrotoxic immunoglobulin light chains (Bence Jones proteins) is the underlying cause of myeloma cast nephropathy and the most common form of acute or subacute kidney injury in patients with multiple myeloma (MM). The light chains cause eosinophilic intratubular cast formation and obstruction. They have a direct toxic effect on the renal tubular epithelial cells, resulting in tubular atrophy. A dipstick urine test cannot detect light chain proteins in the urine since it is specific for albumin.

Besides myeloma cast nephropathy, renal disease in MM patients may be due to various other mechanisms, including AL amyloidosis (usually presenting with nephrotic syndrome due to glomerular dysfunction) or hypercalcemia (causing nephrocalcinosis).

C) INCORRECT:

Renal deposition of AL amyloid suggests a renal manifestation of AL amyloidosis, which may occur in patients with multiple myeloma. However, AL amyloidosis typically affects multiple organ systems, such as the kidneys (nephrotic syndrome with proteinuria and orthostatic hypotension), heart (restrictive cardiomyopathy, atrioventricular block), and gastrointestinal tract (malabsorption syndromes). This patient has no cardiac abnormalities and urinalysis was negative for proteins.

D) INCORRECT:

Anti-dsDNA antibodies are typically found in systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE). By cross-reacting with the glomerular basement membrane, they promote an inflammatory response, which may result in lupus nephritis. This patient's renal failure, lower back pain (possibly due to arthritis), and fatigue do support this diagnosis. However, he lacks other classic findings of underlying SLE, e.g., fever, cardiac abnormalities, and/or a malar rash. Lastly, hematuria and proteinuria are common in lupus nephritis but are not present here.

E) INCORRECT:

Hypersensitivity reaction is the underlying pathomechanism of allergic interstitial nephritis, which may occur in patients with long-term use of analgesic agents, including ibuprofen. However, it usually causes acute inflammation with fever, colicky flank pain (due to papillary necrosis), and/or hematuria, none of which is present in this patient.
questions.hint: This elderly patient presents with features of renal failure including oliguria, peripheral edema (indicating fluid overload), and elevated serum creatinine. His history of fatigue, persistent bone pain, and constipation (which could be due to hypercalcemia), together with the findings of anemia and hypercalcemia, make multiple myeloma the most likely underlying cause.

questions.text: A 60-year-old woman comes to the physician because of lower back pain, generalized weakness, and weight loss that has occurred over the past 6 weeks. She also says that her urine has appeared foamy recently. Physical examination shows focal midline tenderness of the lumbar spine and conjunctival pallor. Her temperature is 100.5°F (38°C). A photomicrograph of a bone marrow biopsy specimen is shown. Further evaluation of this patient is most likely to show which of the following findings?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Helmet cells are crescent-shaped erythrocyte fragments that occur in microangiopathic hemolytic anemia due to mechanical damage to red blood cells. Microangiopathic hemolytic anemia is usually secondary to DIC, HUS, or TTP, which result in the formation of systemic microthrombi. This patient lacks the history and physical findings associated with these conditions, and her bone pain and foamy urine suggest a different pathology.
Image Description:

Peripheral blood smear with normal erythrocytes (E) and schistocytes (dashed circles). One side of the schistocyte retains the typical convex shape of an erythrocyte, while the fragmented side is irregular or concave (green line) and often shows pointed edges. Schistocytes occur due to thrombotic microangiopathies (e.g., due to TTP, DIC, etc.) or mechanical damage (e.g., artificial heart valves).

B) INCORRECT:

Heinz bodies are cytoplasmic hemoglobin inclusions in erythrocytes that can be found in glucose-6-phosphate dehydrogenase (G6PD) deficiency. G6PD deficiency most commonly affects male individuals of African, Asian, and Mediterranean descent, and causes recurring hemolytic crises in response to periods of increased oxidative stress. Patients classically present with back or abdominal pain, jaundice, hematuria, and splenomegaly. This woman's bone marrow biopsy shows plasma cells, and her history of bone pain and foamy urine suggest a different etiology for her symptoms.
Image Description:

Photomicrograph of a peripheral blood smear (new methylene blue stain; high magnification)

Multiple erythrocytes are visible, some of which contain small, round inclusions (examples indicated by arrowheads) called Heinz bodies. Heinz bodies are composed of denatured hemoglobin and are typically associated with G6PD deficiency but are also seen in other conditions.

C) INCORRECT:

B-lymphocytes with radial cytoplasmic projections are characteristic of hairy cell leukemia. This disease most commonly affects middle-aged men and causes cytopenias and profound splenomegaly. Bone marrow aspiration often results in a dry tap. This patient has plasma cells on bone marrow biopsy, bone pain, and proteinuria, which suggest a different pathology.

D) INCORRECT:

Hypersegmented neutrophils are observed on peripheral blood smear in patients with megaloblastic anemia, which is often caused by folate deficiency, vitamin B12 deficiency, or orotic aciduria. Bone marrow biopsy is not necessary for the diagnosis of megaloblastic anemia but typically demonstrates erythroid hyperplasia. This patient's bone marrow biopsy demonstrates plasma cells, which would not be expected in megaloblastic anemia. Her bone pain and foamy urine also suggest a different pathology.
Image Description:

Peripheral blood smear (H&E stain; very high magnification)

A large granulocyte (dashed outline) with a hypersegmented nucleus (blue overlay) is surrounded by red blood cells.

The presence of hypersegmented granulocytes in a peripheral blood smear indicates megaloblastic anemia.

E) CORRECT:

This woman's symptoms and biopsy findings are concerning for multiple myeloma, the most common primary bone tumor in patients 50–70 years of age. Extensive skeletal destruction caused by bone marrow infiltration predisposes affected patients to vertebral compression fractures and anemia, as indicated by this woman's lower back pain, pallor, and weakness. Patients can present with foamy urine due to light chain proteinuria (Bence Jones proteins). Peripheral blood smear often demonstrates grouped erythrocytes with a stacked-coin appearance, known as rouleaux formations, which occur because of elevated serum globulin concentrations.

Bone marrow biopsy is the confirmatory test for patients with suspected multiple myeloma and typically demonstrates > 10% monoclonal plasma cells.
Image Description:

Photomicrograph of a peripheral blood smear

Red blood cells are aggregated in chains and appear like stacked coins (rouleaux formation (illustration); examples indicated by blue overlay).

This phenomenon occurs in disorders with increased serum proteins (e.g., multiple myeloma and Waldenstrom macroglobulinemia).

F) INCORRECT:

Auer rods are needle-shaped cytoplasmic inclusions found within myeloblasts in AML, especially the M3 subtype. Although this patient's weakness and pallor could result from leukemia, other common findings in AML include thrombocytopenia, hepatosplenomegaly, and CNS involvement, which are absent here. Bone marrow biopsy is the confirmatory diagnostic test for AML and demonstrates homogeneous, hypercellular bone marrow with > 20% myeloblasts, rather than the plasma cells seen in this patient's biopsy.
Image Description:

Photomicrograph of a bone marrow smear (Wright-Giemsa stain, high magnification)

Promyelocytes with azurophilic granules can be seen as well as a myeloblast containing multiple violet, rod-like intracytoplasmic inclusion bodies, known as Auer rods (examples indicated by yellow lines).

Auer rods are typically seen in certain types of acute myeloid leukemia (e.g., APL) and in myelodysplastic syndromes.
questions.hint: The image of this patient's bone marrow biopsy specimen shows plasma cells. Bone pain, weight loss, low-grade fever, and frothy urine (suggestive of proteinuria) in a 60-year-old woman are highly suspicious for a malignant disease that is characterized by uncontrolled plasma cell proliferation.

questions.text: A 69-year-old woman comes to the physician because of a 3-week history of headache and worsening vision. Ophthalmologic examination shows a visual acuity of 20/120 in the right eye and 20/80 in the left eye. Physical examination shows no other abnormalities. Laboratory studies show a hemoglobin of 14.2 g/dL and total serum calcium of 9.9 mg/dL. A photomicrograph of a peripheral blood smear is shown. Serum electrophoresis shows increased concentration of a pentameric immunoglobulin. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Increased immunoglobulin concentration, rouleaux formation, and features of hyperviscosity syndrome (e.g., headache, worsening vision) can occur in patients with multiple myeloma. However, the excess immunoglobulins found in multiple myeloma are usually IgG or IgA, which do not form pentamers. Furthermore, multiple myeloma usually manifests with hypercalcemia, plasma cells on a peripheral blood smear, and painful lytic bone lesions, which are not present in this patient.
Image Description:

Photomicrograph of a bone marrow specimen (H&E stain)

Plasma cells are large cells that typically have an eccentric nucleus (hatched overlay) with dense, clumped chromatin. The cytoplasm is deeply basophilic due to the abundance of rough endoplasmic reticulum required for the synthesis of antibodies.

B) INCORRECT:

Elevated concentration of pentameric immunoglobulins (IgM) is seen in patients with hyper IgM syndrome. However, patients with this disorder usually develop features such as failure to thrive and recurrent infections during infancy. Rouleaux formation and features of hyperviscosity syndrome (e.g., headache, worsening vision) would not be expected in this condition. Also, the most common form of hyper IgM syndrome (CD40 ligand deficiency) is an X-linked recessive disorder, so females are not usually affected.

C) INCORRECT:

Blurred vision and headache are typical symptoms of essential thrombocythemia. However, a peripheral blood smear would show thrombocytosis with aggregates of platelets rather than rouleaux formation of RBCs or elevated immunoglobulin.

D) CORRECT:

Waldenstrom macroglobulinemia is a plasma cell dyscrasia characterized by abnormal proliferation of terminally differentiated B cells that produce monoclonal IgM antibodies. Excess production leads to formation of cold agglutinins with hyperviscosity syndrome. Impaired vision and constitutional symptoms (e.g., fatigue, headache) commonly result. As in this patient, hemoglobin and total serum calcium concentrations are typically normal.

E) INCORRECT:

Headaches and visual disturbances are common symptoms of giant cell arteritis. Rouleaux formation of RBCs may also be seen due to increase in ESR but elevated immunoglobulin concentration would not be expected.
questions.hint: Only antibodies of the IgM type form pentamers.

questions.text:
A 74-year-old man comes to the physician because of a 3-month history of fatigue and hip pain. During this period, he has also had a 5-kg (11-lb) weight loss despite no change in appetite. He has not noticed any blood in his urine. He has a history of major depressive disorder and hypertension. His medications are fluoxetine and amlodipine. He has smoked one-half pack of cigarettes daily for 30 years. He appears tired. His pulse is 90/min, respirations are 18/min, and blood pressure is 135/85 mm Hg. Examination shows pale conjunctivae. Range of motion of the right hip is limited by pain. The remainder of the examination shows no abnormalities. Laboratory studies show:


Hemoglobin
8.2 g/dL


Serum



 Calcium

11.4 mg/dL


 Urea nitrogen
36 mg/dL


 Creatinine

2.2 mg/dL


 Na+

141 mEq/L


 K+

4.0 mEq/L


 Cl-

101 mEq/L


 ALT
25 mg/dL


 AST
28 mg/dL


A CT scan of the abdomen and pelvis shows multiple lytic lesions in the right ilium. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Primary hyperparathyroidism (pHPT) can manifest with bone pain, weight loss, and psychological symptoms (e.g., fatigue, depression), and hypercalcemia. Furthermore, hyperparathyroidism can, rarely, cause osteolytic lesions (Brown tumors). However, other typical manifestations of pHPT include nephrolithiasis (e.g., flank pain, hematuria), lack of appetite, and constipation. Moreover, anemia is not an expected finding.

B) INCORRECT:

Monoclonal gammopathy of undetermined significance (MGUS) is typically seen in individuals 45–75 years of age and is characterized by the production of abnormal immunoglobulins. MGUS is not, by definition, associated with any accompanying clinical symptoms or evidence of organ damage. This patient, however, has hypercalcemia, renal insufficiency, anemia, and bone lesions.

C) CORRECT:

Multiple myeloma (MM) is characterized by uncontrolled proliferation and the diffuse infiltration of monoclonal plasma cells in the bone marrow, resulting in activation of osteoclasts and leading to painful, lytic bone lesions and consequent hypercalcemia. Bone marrow infiltration by malignant plasma cells also causes suppression of hematopoiesis, which often results in anemia, leukopenia, and thrombocytopenia. Constitutional symptoms are also common. The overproduction of immunoglobulin light chains (Bence Jones proteins) and hypercalcemia lead to myeloma cast nephropathy, which manifests with increased serum creatinine. Along with symptoms of organ damage (see CRAB criteria), a bone marrow biopsy showing ≥ 10% clonal plasma cells confirms the diagnosis.

Infections are a major cause of death in patients with MM; the immunoglobulins produced by MM cells are monoclonal and, thus, nonfunctional, resulting in immunodeficiency and an increased risk of developing infections.

D) INCORRECT:

Waldenstrom macroglobulinemia can manifest with anemia, and constitutional symptoms. However, typical manifestations include hyperviscosity syndrome (e.g., vision and hearing loss, headaches, Raynaud phenomenon) and progressive neuropathy. Moreover, hypercalcemia and bone lesions are not expected findings.

E) INCORRECT:

Chondrosarcoma typically occurs in individuals > 50 years of age and manifests with lytic bone lesions in the pelvis, bone pain, and hypercalcemia, similar to what is seen here. However, impaired renal function and anemia are not expected findings.

F) INCORRECT:

Metastatic renal cell carcinoma (RCC) can manifest with constitutional symptoms (e.g., weight loss, fatigue), anemia, bone pain, and hypercalcemia. However, this patient lacks typical findings of RCC, such as macroscopic hematuria, flank pain, and/or a palpable renal mass. Moreover, CT scan of the abdomen and pelvis would show a renal mass in addition to the lytic bone lesions.
questions.hint: Patients with this condition typically have an overproduction of abnormal immunoglobulins (typically IgG and IgA) and/or immunoglobulin fragments.

questions.text:
A 51-year-old woman comes to the physician for evaluation of elevated total protein of the blood that was found incidentally during a routine health maintenance examination 1 week ago. She has no history of serious illness and takes no medications. She reports feeling well. Vital signs are within normal limits. Physical examination shows no abnormalities. Laboratory studies show:


Hemoglobin
13.1 g/dL


Leukocyte count
9800/mm3 with a normal differential


Platelet count
210,000/mm3



Serum



Ca2+

9.1 mg/dL


Proteins, total
8.7 g/dL


Albumin
4.6 g/dL


Globulin
4.1 g/dL


Creatinine
0.9 g/dL


A peripheral blood smear shows no abnormalities. Serum protein electrophoresis with immunofixation shows an M-protein spike due to IgG heavy chains and quantitative assessment shows an M-protein concentration of 0.7 g/dL. A serum-free light chain assay shows normal kappa and lambda light chain concentrations and a normal free light chain ratio. Electrophoresis and immunofixation of a 24-hour urine specimen and bone densitometry show no abnormalities. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Rituximab is used to treat WM, which would cause IgM (not IgG!) paraproteinemia. This patient has MGUS, which does not require any medication.

B) CORRECT:

The initial workup of paraproteinemia consists of a CBC, serum creatinine and calcium measurement, immunofixation electrophoresis of serum protein (SPEP) and urine protein (UPEP), and SFLC studies. A provisional diagnosis of MGUS can be reached without bone marrow biopsy or imaging to screen for focal abnormalities (e.g., lytic bone lesions, mesenteric lymphadenopathy) if the following are present: IgG paraproteinemia with an M-protein concentration < 1.5 g/dL, normal SFLC studies and, on the initial evaluation, no findings suggestive of a severe PCD. In patients with these traits, the risk of transformation to a severe PCD is low (approx. 0.25% per year). Follow-up is required only after six months and annually thereafter, with monitoring of CBC, serum creatinine and calcium, SPEP, and SFLC studies.

Findings on the initial evaluation that would suggest a severe PCD include features of MM (e.g., bone pain, anemia, hypercalcemia, increased creatinine), WM (e.g., hyperviscosity syndrome, peripheral lymphadenopathy), and AL amyloidosis (e.g., neuropathy, organomegaly). UPEP is normal if there is no light chain proliferation; light chains (e.g., Bence Jones proteins) are filtered across the glomeruli while heavy chains are not. Individuals with MGUS have an increased risk of developing osteoporosis and should therefore undergo bone densitometry at the time of diagnosis.

C) INCORRECT:

Plasmapheresis removes paraproteins and is indicated in the management of patients with WM who develop hyperviscosity syndrome. Patients with WM would have IgM (not IgG!) paraproteinemia and this woman does not have any evidence of hyperviscosity syndrome (e.g., headache, impaired vision). The paraproteinemia in MGUS is mild and does not need to be treated with plasmapheresis.

D) INCORRECT:

A low-dose whole-body CT scan or a skeletal survey using radiographs (when CT is not available) is used to screen patients with non-IgM paraproteinemia for an osteolytic lesion. The presence of an osteolytic lesion is a myeloma-defining event (“B” of the CRAB criteria) and changes the diagnosis from MGUS to MM. However, imaging for focal bone lesions is only required if evidence from the initial evaluation indicates a moderate to high risk for the transformation of MGUS into MM (i.e., M-protein concentration of 1.5–2.9 g/dL, IgD or IgA M-proteins, abnormal SFLC studies) or that transformation to MM has already occurred (i.e., M-protein concentration ≥ 3 g/dL, findings of MM).

E) INCORRECT:

A bone marrow biopsy can be used to identify plasma cell proliferation, the distinctive feature of all PCDs. The presence of ≥ 10% monoclonal plasma cells on biopsy would rule out MGUS and confirm transformation to a severe PCD. However, bone marrow biopsy is only required if there is evidence from the initial evaluation to indicate that there is a moderate to high risk for transformation of MGUS into another PCD (i.e., M-protein concentration of 1.5–2.9 g/dL, non-IgG M-proteins, abnormal SFLC studies) or that transformation to a severe PCD has already occurred (i.e., M-protein concentration ≥ 3 g/dL, findings of a severe PCD).

F) INCORRECT:

A CT scan of the abdomen to screen for mesenteric lymphadenopathy is performed if the patient has MGUS with IgM paraproteinemia and a moderate to high risk of transformation of MGUS into WM (lymphoplasmacytic lymphoma). The presence of mesenteric lymphadenopathy would change the diagnosis of MGUS to WM. Imaging to screen for mesenteric lymphadenopathy is not indicated in patients with non-IgM MGUS. This type of MGUS transforms into MM or AL amyloidosis, neither of which causes lymphadenopathy.
questions.hint: Monoclonal paraproteins (M-proteins) in an otherwise healthy patient indicate monoclonal gammopathy of undetermined significance (MGUS), which is the most common type of plasma cell dyscrasia (PCD). The prevalence of MGUS increases with age and although MGUS is initially benign, it is the precursor to severe PCDs such as multiple myeloma (MM), Waldenstrom macroglobulinemia (WM), and primary amyloidosis (AL). Risk stratification is based on the type and concentration of the M-protein, as well as results of serum-free light chain (SFLC) studies, guide the management of MGUS.

questions.text:
A 70-year-old woman presents with back pain. She was recently diagnosed with a T8 vertebral fracture and immunoglobulin G kappa multiple myeloma that is complicated by diffuse skeletal lesions.
She has a creatinine level of 1.9 mg/dL (reference range, 0.6–1.1) and a calculated glomerular filtration rate of 28 mL/min/1.73 m2 (≥ 60). Her serum calcium and vitamin D levels are within normal limits.
Treatment with dexamethasone and bortezomib is started.
Which one of the following additional medications is most appropriate for this patient?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

In this particular case, bisphosphonates are contraindicated because the patient has stage 4 chronic kidney disease (CKD); pamidronate can be used (with dose adjustment) in CKD up to stage 3 but is not recommended once CKD reaches stage 4.

B) INCORRECT:

Calcium and vitamin D supplements are not sufficient to reduce skeletal events and may worsen hypercalcemia.

C) INCORRECT:

Cinacalcet is a calcium-receptor agonist that is not indicated to prevent fractures in patients with myeloma. It is indicated for patients with hypercalcemia associated with parathyroid carcinoma and for severe hypercalcemia in patients with primary hyperparathyroidism who are unable to undergo parathyroid surgery.

D) CORRECT:

Patients receiving primary therapy for multiple myeloma with skeletal lesions should be considered candidates for at least 2 years of treatment with an osteoclast inhibitor, such as an intravenous bisphosphonate (e.g., zoledronic acid or pamidronate) or denosumab, to help reduce the risk for pathologic fractures. In this particular case, bisphosphonates are contraindicated because the patient has stage 4 chronic kidney disease (CKD); pamidronate can be used (with dose adjustment) in CKD up to stage 3 but is not recommended once CKD reaches stage 4. Therefore, denosumab, a monoclonal antibody targeting the receptor activator of nuclear factor kappa-B ligand (RANKL), is the best option in this case. Denosumab has been shown to have skeletal benefits similar to those of bisphosphonates and can be used in patients with CKD who are not on dialysis, although it is more expensive than a bisphosphonate and is associated with higher rates of hypocalcemia.

Key learning point: A patient with multiple myeloma and lytic bone lesions should be treated with an osteoclast inhibitor, such as an intravenous bisphosphonate or denosumab.

E) INCORRECT:

Calcitonin is used to treat acute hypercalcemia but not skeletal lesions in patients with multiple myeloma.

questions.text:
A 70-year-old man presents for follow-up after laboratory testing revealed an elevated total protein level of 9.0 g/dL (reference range, 5.5–8.0) and an albumin level of 3.4 g/dL (3.5–5.5). He states that he does not experience bone pain, fevers, night sweats, weight loss, fatigue, numbness, or dizziness. Physical examination is unremarkable.
On further laboratory testing, the hemoglobin, leukocyte count, platelet count, calcium level, and serum creatinine level are normal. Serum protein electrophoresis shows a monoclonal protein measuring 1.4 g/dL, and immunofixation shows this band to be immunoglobulin G kappa. The serum free-light-chain-kappa-to-lambda ratio is 1.90 (reference range, 0.26–1.65).
Urine protein electrophoresis and immunofixation show no monoclonal protein. A bone survey shows no lytic bone lesions or fractures. A bone-marrow biopsy and aspirate reveal 6% plasma cells.
Which one of the following management approaches is most appropriate for this patient?

choices.text: Initiate treatment with dexamethasone and bortezomib
Repeat bone-marrow biopsy in one year

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

There is no evidence that treatment improves outcomes in patients with MGUS.

B) INCORRECT:

A fat-pad biopsy for amyloid is indicated only if clinical signs or symptoms suggest primary amyloidosis.

C) CORRECT:

Monoclonal gammopathy of undetermined significance (MGUS) is, by definition, an asymptomatic disorder. It is often discovered incidentally on laboratory evaluation. If the initial laboratory evaluation is satisfactory, then serum electrophoresis can be repeated in approximately 3 months and then at 6- to 12-month intervals with complete blood count, serum calcium and creatinine levels, and monoclonal protein in serum and urine.

The primary concern with MGUS is progression to a malignant plasma-cell disorder such as multiple myeloma (MM), Waldenstrom macroglobulinemia, or primary amyloidosis. For patients with low-risk MGUS, the risk of progression is 1% per year. Features associated with increased risk for progression include the following:

• A serum monoclonal protein level >1.5 g/dL
• Non-immunoglobulin G monoclonal protein
• A markedly abnormal free-light-chain-kappa-to-lambda ratio

Patients possessing all three of these risk factors have a 58% chance of disease progression within 20 years. Patients with any of the high-risk features warrant annual surveillance; patients without them do not necessarily require follow-up.

Key learning point: The combination of monoclonal protein detected in serum at a level <3.0 g/dL; <10% plasma cells in bone marrow; and the absence of hypercalcemia, renal failure, anemia, and lytic bone lesions is consistent with a diagnosis of monoclonal gammopathy of undetermined significance.

D) INCORRECT:

Bone scans are not recommended for surveillance for multiple myeloma because sensitivity for detecting purely lytic lesions is poor.

E) INCORRECT:

A bone-marrow aspirate is recommended initially for patients with monoclonal protein concentrations >1.5 g/dL. Repeat surveillance with bone-marrow aspirate is not routinely performed but should be considered if progression to multiple myeloma is suspected.

questions.text:
An 82-year-old woman is brought to the hospital in a confused state. She describes a one-week history of progressive headache, lower-extremity numbness and tingling, and blurred vision.
She is afebrile, her blood pressure is 130/90 mm Hg, and her heart rate is 90 beats per minute. She is oriented to name only. Retinal examination is significant for dilated retinal veins. She has several areas of ecchymosis on her lower extremities.
She is up to date with Covid-19 vaccinations, and testing for SARS-CoV-2 is negative. Laboratory results are as follows:



Patient value
Reference range


Hemoglobin (g/dL)
7.0
12.0–16.0


Leukocyte count (per mm3)
13,000
4500–11,000


Platelet count (per mm3)
100,000
150,000–350,000


Creatinine (mg/dL)
0.9
0.6–1.1



Immunoglobulin M (mg/dL)
5000
53–334


Serum viscosity (centipoise)
7.0
1.4–1.8


A bone-marrow biopsy demonstrates 30% infiltration by small plasmacytoid lymphocytes.
Which one of the following diagnoses is most likely in this case?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Chronic myeloid leukemia is usually associated with a higher leukocyte count, and the bone marrow shows evidence of increased granulocytes.

B) CORRECT:

Waldenström macroglobulinemia, a rare condition that occurs most frequently late in life, is characterized by lymphoplasmacytic lymphoma in the bone marrow with an immunoglobulin M (IgM) monoclonal gammopathy in the blood.

Hyperviscosity syndrome associated with Waldenström macroglobulinemia is caused by elevated levels of IgM, which causes impaired blood flow to the central nervous system. Symptoms of hyperviscosity include blurred vision, headache, dyspnea, neuropathy, retinal vein engorgement, and mental status changes. Treatment for hyperviscosity syndrome is urgent plasmapheresis to remove IgM from the circulation. The decision to initiate plasmapheresis is based on serum viscosity level, symptoms, and physical examination findings. Because 80% of IgM antibodies remain intravascular, plasmapheresis is an effective but temporary method of reducing viscosity.

Key learning point: The most likely diagnosis for a patient with features of hyperviscosity who is found to have plasmacytoid lymphocytes in the bone marrow is Waldenström macroglobulinemia.

C) INCORRECT:

Multiple myeloma, characterized by plasma cells in the bone marrow, is usually associated with an immunoglobulin G paraproteinemia.

D) INCORRECT:

Lymphoplasmacytic lymphoma is a subtype of non-Hodgkin lymphoma; however, more than 40 types of lymphoma exist. In this patient, the clinical and laboratory findings allow for a more specific diagnosis.

E) INCORRECT:

A diagnosis of acute lymphoblastic leukemia generally requires the presence of at least 20% bone-marrow lymphoblasts.

questions.text:
A 55-year-old woman presents for her annual physical examination. She feels well and is physically active.
Laboratory testing yields the following results:

Reference range

4600
4500–11,000

14.2
12.0–16.0


Platelet count (per mm3)
152,000
150,000–350,000


Total bilirubin (mg/dL)
0.5
0.3–1.0


Creatinine (mg/dL)
1.0
0.6–1.1


Total protein (g/dL)
9.5
5.5–8.0


Calcium (mg/dL)
10.0
9.0–10.5


Albumin (g/dL)
4.3
3.5–5.5


Serum protein electrophoresis documents a monoclonal protein level of 3.5 g/dL, subsequently identified as immunoglobulin G lambda. A serum beta-2-microglobulin level is not elevated. The kappa-lambda serum free-light-chain ratio is normal at 1.45 (reference range, 0.26–1.65).
A skeletal survey demonstrates osteopenia but no lytic bone lesions. Bone-marrow examination shows 15% clonal plasma cells.
Which one of the following management strategies is most appropriate for this patient?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

No specific treatment other than close observation is indicated for low- or intermediate-risk smoldering multiple myeloma or monoclonal gammopathy of undetermined significance, unless the patient has features to suggest a poor prognosis without treatment.

B) CORRECT:

The presence of a monoclonal protein (M-protein) in the serum may be a sign of monoclonal gammopathy of undetermined significance (MGUS), smoldering (asymptomatic) multiple myeloma, or symptomatic multiple myeloma (MM).

In this case, the patient’s clinical findings are consistent with smoldering (asymptomatic) MM (see "Diagnostic criteria for plasma cell dyscrasias" table).

The risk of progression from asymptomatic to symptomatic MM can be estimated using the Mayo Clinic 2018 risk stratification system, which considers three risk factors:

• M protein >2 g/dL
• Bone marrow clonal plasma cells >20%
• Involved-uninvolved free-light-chain ratio >20

Patients are considered to be at low risk if they have no risk factors, intermediate risk if they have one risk factor (as in this case), or high risk if they have 2 or 3 risk factors.

MGUS and low- or intermediate-risk smoldering MM are best managed with close observation. According to the International Myeloma Working Group, patients whose smoldering MM is being managed with observation alone should undergo surveillance testing 2 to 3 months after initial diagnosis. If stable, the patient should be monitored every 4 to 6 months for one year. Stable patients who remain asymptomatic without evidence of end-organ damage can then be followed every 6 to 12 months.

No specific treatment other than close observation is indicated for low- or intermediate-risk smoldering MM or MGUS, unless the patient has features to suggest a poor prognosis without treatment (such as a high burden of clonal cells in the marrow or an elevated serum beta2-microglobulin). Patients with high-risk smoldering MM may be considered for therapy such as a combination of lenalidomide and dexamethasone.

If signs of end-organ damage develop (hypercalcemia, lytic bone disease, anemia, or renal failure), then the patient has symptomatic (or active) MM and treatment is indicated.

Key learning point: Patients with low- or intermediate-risk smoldering multiple myeloma are best managed with close clinical and laboratory surveillance.

C) INCORRECT:

No specific treatment other than close observation is indicated for low- or intermediate-risk smoldering multiple myeloma or monoclonal gammopathy of undetermined significance, unless the patient has features to suggest a poor prognosis without treatment.

D) INCORRECT:

Daratumumab, a monoclonal antibody targeting CD38, is a treatment for symptomatic multiple myeloma (MM); it is not used for smoldering MM.

E) INCORRECT:

No specific treatment other than close observation is indicated for low- or intermediate-risk smoldering multiple myeloma or monoclonal gammopathy of undetermined significance, unless the patient has features to suggest a poor prognosis without treatment. Patients with high-risk smoldering multiple myeloma may be considered for therapy such as a combination of lenalidomide and dexamethasone.

questions.text:
A 67-year-old man with back pain is diagnosed with a fracture of the fifth lumbar vertebra. He reports an 8-week history of progressive weakness, dyspnea on exertion, and a 6-kg unintentional weight loss. His medical history is significant for hypertension, which is treated with lisinopril and hydrochlorothiazide.
His blood pressure is 137/92 mm Hg, and his heart rate is 97 beats per minute. His skin is pale, and he has bilateral pitting edema of the lower extremities. His serum creatinine level is 2.3 mg/dL (reference range, 0.8–1.3), compared with 1.3 mg/dL measured 4 months earlier.
Laboratory testing yields the following results:



Patient value
Reference range


Leukocyte count (per mm3)
7000
4500–11,000



Hemoglobin (g/dL)
10.0
13.5–17.5


Platelet count (per mm3)
175,000
150,000–350,000



Calcium (mg/dL)
12.0
9.0–10.5


Albumin (g/dL)
3.2
3.5–5.5


Urinalysis results reveal 2 white cells per high-power field (reference range, 0–2) and 5 red cells per high-power field (0–2). Urine dipstick shows 1+ blood and no protein.
A renal ultrasound shows no evidence of obstruction.
Which one of the following diagnostic tests is most likely to identify the cause of this patient’s acute kidney injury?

choices.text: Measurement of fractional excretion of sodium

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

The peripheral-blood smear is appropriate in a patient with anemia, but findings are unlikely to provide sufficient information to explain the renal failure.

B) INCORRECT:

Urine calcium measurement can be used in the evaluation of hypercalcemia or nephrolithiasis but would not help determine the cause of this constellation of symptoms.

C) INCORRECT:

The measurement of antineutrophilic cytoplasmic antibodies is not appropriate for this patient, given that the presentation is not suggestive of either glomerulonephritis or vasculitis.

D) INCORRECT:

The fractional excretion of sodium is useful to help differentiate prerenal azotemia from acute tubular necrosis in the correct clinical setting. Here, there are so many features suggestive of myeloma that this urinary test is unlikely to be useful.

E) CORRECT:

The clinical presentation of bone pain, anemia, and hypercalcemia is most consistent with a diagnosis of multiple myeloma. Renal insufficiency is common in myeloma and may be caused by multiple different mechanisms. The most common of these is cast nephropathy from light chains that occlude the renal tubules and produce interstitial inflammation. In this disorder, the urine dipstick may be negative for protein because the dipstick detects only albumin, not the light chains that cause this disorder. Renal dysfunction may develop in patients with myeloma as a result of associated amyloidosis and light-chain deposition disease, both of which are associated with albuminuria. Serum and urine protein electrophoresis with immunofixation and measurement of serum free-light-chain levels would be the next step to diagnose multiple myeloma in a patient with this combination of findings.

Key learning point: Patients with the co-occurrence of anemia, hypercalcemia, and lytic bone lesions should be evaluated for multiple myeloma with serum and urine protein electrophoresis with immunofixation and measurement of serum free-light-chain levels.

questions.text:
A 60-year-old man presents with fatigue that has worsened during the past few weeks. He has chronic kidney disease that is attributed to nonsteroidal antiinflammatory drugs that he took regularly for back pain. He has no history of hypertension, type 2 diabetes, cardiac disease, or lung disease. He states that he does not experience anorexia, vomiting, diarrhea, or lower urinary tract symptoms. He no longer takes any over-the-counter medications. A screening colonoscopy done 3 months ago was normal.
Vital signs and physical examination today are unremarkable.
Laboratory testing yields the following results:



Patient value 6 months ago
Patient value today

Hemoglobin (g/dL)
